g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
The Scope of the Energy System and its Possible Evolution
ystems are defined broadly to include both physical and societal elements. The
physical infrastructure includes all the infrastructure and equipment used to extract, transform,
broad range of societal systems and dynamics are relevant to the energy system. Human societies use
energy to transport themselves and the goods that they use and consume, to heat, cool, and light their
to produce goods and services. Energy systems are therefore tied to the
systems involved in the provision of these various goods and services. All energy users engage in the
operation of energy systems by demanding energy at particular times and in pa
and demands, for example, by using less energy or by
governments invest in equipment to produce, transform, and transport energy
refineries, electric transmission lines, and oil tankers
. All aspects of energy systems ar
laws, regulations, and actual institutions that reside within businesses and governments at all levels
, water management and related environmental rules that
define the availability of hydropower or influence water availability for cooling power plants,
into underground reservoirs or disposing of nuclear waste, and even
ompany policies regarding work hours or teleworking, which can have important implications for
energy demand profiles. Many people are employed in the energy sector, and energy system mitigation
will eliminate some jobs while creating others.
view of energy systems is essential for understanding energy system mitigation, as these
broader societal and institutional factors can have an important influence on energy system
transformations and the potential to rapidly reduce energy CO
as much about the challenges of societal change as it is about the challenges of changes in physical
infrastructure, technologies, and operations. While this chapter does not attempt to draw a specific
fferent systems that interact with the energy system, it frequently explores
these broader system interactions when assessing different mit
is no single spatial scale at which energy systems might be defined and assesse
assessed at the scales of homes, cities, states or provinces, countries, regions, or the entire world. These
different scales are frequently both distinct with their own internal dynamics yet also connected to one
energy systems from the country and global perspective
Because the energy system is so complex, it can be hard to define particular parts of it precisely, and
there may be competing definitions in the literature. For the purposes of t
all primary energy, conversion, and transmission processes with the exception of those
that use final energy to provide energy services in the end
” is used for energy technologies that produce little CO
used to describe transitions that limit likely
zero” energy systems refer to those that produce very little or no CO
